thread.title: Preseason votes put Lobos at 6th in Mountain West
thread.title_full: Preseason votes put Lobos at 6th in Mountain West

title: Preseason votes put Lobos at 6th in Mountain West
text: Preseason votes put Lobos at 6th in Mountain West Junior selected as conference newcomer of the year UPDATED 10:16 AM MDT Oct 13, 2015 A Large Text Photos Last year’s regular-season Mountain West co-champions are favorites to finish the 2015-16 season atop the conference, according to votes from conference media. San Diego State University and Boise State University are picked to finish first and second, respectively, each receiving more than 200 votes. The SDSU Aztecs received 22 of a possible 25 first-place votes. For the second consecutive year, the Broncos claimed the second spot. Utah State University received 190 points to land in third place, while the University of New Mexico received 164 votes for sixth. San Diego State compiled a 27-9 record overall and a 14-4 mark in Mountain West play last season en route to a share of the regular-season title with Boise State. No UNM Lobos were named to the 2015-16 preseason all-Mountain West team, though junior Tim Williams was named preseason newcomer of the year. Williams, a junior from Flossmoor, Illinois, redshirted in 2014-15 after transferring from Samford University. As a sophomore, he earned All-SoCon first-team honors while leading the Bulldogs in points (17.6) and rebounds (7.5). Williams shot 60.3 percent from the field, a figure that ranked seventh nationally. In his first collegiate season, Williams earned SoCon Freshman of the Year honors after averaging 14.2 points and 7.1 rebounds per contest. In two seasons with the Bulldogs, he scored in double digits in 58 games. The Lobos finished 15-16 overall in 2014-15 with a 7-11 conference record. They were knocked out in the first round of the MWC end-of-season tournament. 2015-16 PRESEASON MEN’S BASKETBALL PREDICTED ORDER OF FINISH Rk. Team (First-Place Votes) Pts. 1. San Diego State (22) 272 2. Boise State (2) 234 3. Utah State 190 5. Fresno State (1) 182 6. New Mexico 164
